instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight kills eDP over and over
threads.message:
No liquid damage at all.

Came in with no backlight.
No short on LCD connector.
Being brain lazy I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>.
Connected new screen and sure enough it provided power to <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.... Power to short the connector and kill the cable.

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>, got another screen on there, killed the connector but not the cable this time.
Checked feedback, resistor values <RESISTOR>R7708</RESISTOR> = 17k26 and <RESISTOR>R7709</RESISTOR> = 149k5.

Can't find a datasheet on <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> <CHIP>LP5849</CHIP> (could just be dumb).
LED return resistors are all 0R. Schematic says LED return <in on pin 2 of each return and then on <CHIP>U7750</CHIP> it says out, WTF.
No Idea what is going on here.

Any help please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight kills eDP over and over
threads.message: Did it fry pin 1 of the connector?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight kills eDP over and over
threads.message:
Yes, pin one is cooked this time

Far too tired now but I'll replace it [I]again[/I] after some sleep.
I will also remove hinge cover and check the number on the screens, just to be double sure.

Not sure what else could be shorting it out like this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight kills eDP over and over
threads.message: Nothing can cause this besides a bad connector/cable/LCD. The connector on the LCD side also is prone to shorting and could kill if there is no fuse on the board.
